content: I'm a Jewish person living in Texas in 2018. I've never felt oppressed or threatened because of my religion. Until now. This happened yesterday in Georgia. In 2018.,pic.twitter.com/W27pMamDAf
Would you like your "black card" via UPS, or FedEx?  Welcome to our world, sleeping Suzanne

This has been a recurring theme on this thread, but your tone feels particularly derogatory and I'm curious as to why. I fully acknowledge that I am white and privileged and that I can't even begin to understand what it's like to be black in America.

On the thread alone, I've gone to battle IN ALL CAPS with numerous racist assholes about BLM. (Some) white people are the worst. I see and hear about systemic racism but haven’t experienced it directly as a white woman.

So isn’t the fact that I personally felt an instance of oppression an active way in for me, as an outsider, to directly empathize/relate to the experiences of POC? Won’t this ultimately help me to be a better ally?
I'm asking because I sincerely want to understand. I am listening.

False flagger to sow division is my guess.
We are all in this together.

Agree with your assessment. We need to pause before we respond to posts like this. Russian bots & trolls are constantly and actively continuing to tweet divisive propaganda. They want to destroy our democracy and our sense of patriotism. We can’t let them succeed. Divided we fall
Agreed
And now you realize how Palestine feels.
Can we please not do that? Jews have been oppressed. Palestinians have been oppressed. We've all been oppressed! It's not a contest!

Your post just screamed like someone who suddenly feels what's it's like to feel oppressed. Sorry if it came across wrong. I'm not into any religion - I'm just sad people feel the need to force religion on others. I couldn't give a shit what people believe in

As a non-believer myself, I kindly have to ask you to close your mouth. She didn't force her religion on anyone, she was just trying to make people aware of the antisemitism that is sadly still very real. You're making this more about religion than it actually is.

I didn't say she forced religion on anyone. We all know it - it's real. So is the things happening against the palestine people.

Forcing others to believe what you believe/saying you have the divine right is... well.
You're derailing. A religion and a State are nothing alike, and you know that perfectly well. Your comment had nothing to do here, go know-it-all people who aren't sharing their very real fears.
Stop distributing this image.
Why? It happened. This happened. It needs to be seen. It needs to be distributed. People need to understand what is happening. What are you even saying?
The image is disturbing and pregnant. You can't control it's use. Nor can I.
Please censor this photo is what you asked. Maybe the USA isn't for you.

Jerry - the wrong people are already passing this image around to each other. IMO, the only thing we (i.e. not Nazis) accomplish by censoring this is that others are allowed to remain ignorant of the fact that it is rearing it's ugly head again.
Spread the word, & fight it.

I have 2 answers:
1) Xianity has stuff in it that can be interpreted to blame Jews for the death of Jesus. Further the Messiah can't come back until everyone believes. (Religious)
…

…
2) modern anti-Semitism is not religious but social. Jews throughout AD Euro history have been a minority group easy to scapegoat & even force into positions/careers that were unattractive to Xians. 
This was highlighted in the Inquisition, Blood Libel, & programs 
…

… 
Fast forward to Depression Germany and these patterns of stereophony and scapegoating were almost automatic, this the Nazi message was easy to accept. 

The US version focused more on blacks, but still talks about white purity and makes Jews non-white. 
…

…
There is still systemic anti-Semitism in the US beyond the Nazi stupidity. It's hard to see, and not overt. But there.  More about dislike of behaviors most associated with Jews instead disliking Jews. (I'll stop there)

It's also good to remember the slavery takes huge amounts of hate and dehumanization. This doesn't disappear for generations. 

We can remember the story of Exodus, and how it's authors understood the need for a new generation unscarred by slavery had to first be made b4 Israel.
